desc: A class for representing two-dimensional rectangles whose properties are immutable.
name: dart:math.Rectangle

methods.desc:
Create a rectangle spanned by (left, top) and (left+width, top+height).

The rectangle contains the points with x-coordinate between left and left + width, and with y-coordinate between top and top + height, both inclusive.

The width and height should be non-negative. If width or height are negative, they are clamped to zero.

If width and height are zero, the "rectangle" comprises only the single point (left, top).
methods.example:
Implementation

const Rectangle(this.left, this.top, T width, T height)
    : this.width = (width < 0) ? -width * 0 : width, // Inline _clampToZero.
      this.height = (height < 0) ? -height * 0 : height;
methods.name: Rectangle

methods.desc: Returns a new rectangle which completely contains this and other.
methods.example:
Implementation

Rectangle<T> boundingBox(Rectangle<T> other) {
  var right = max(this.left + this.width, other.left + other.width);
  var bottom = max(this.top + this.height, other.top + other.height);

  var left = min(this.left, other.left);
  var top = min(this.top, other.top);

  return Rectangle<T>(left, top, right - left, bottom - top);
}
methods.name: boundingBox

methods.desc: Tests whether another is inside or along the edges of this.
methods.example:
Implementation

bool containsPoint(Point<num> another) {
  return another.x >= left &&
      another.x <= left + width &&
      another.y >= top &&
      another.y <= top + height;
}
methods.name: containsPoint

methods.example:
Implementation

bool containsRectangle(Rectangle<num> another) {
  return left <= another.left &&
      left + width >= another.left + another.width &&
      top <= another.top &&
      top + height >= another.top + another.height;
}
methods.name: containsRectangle

methods.desc:
Computes the intersection of this and other.

The intersection of two axis-aligned rectangles, if any, is always another axis-aligned rectangle.

Returns the intersection of this and other, or null if they don't intersect.
methods.example:
Implementation

Rectangle<T> intersection(Rectangle<T> other) {
  var x0 = max(left, other.left);
  var x1 = min(left + width, other.left + other.width);

  if (x0 <= x1) {
    var y0 = max(top, other.top);
    var y1 = min(top + height, other.top + other.height);

    if (y0 <= y1) {
      return Rectangle<T>(x0, y0, x1 - x0, y1 - y0);
    }
  }
  return null;
}
methods.name: intersection

methods.example:
Implementation

bool intersects(Rectangle<num> other) {
  return (left <= other.left + other.width &&
      other.left <= left + width &&
      top <= other.top + other.height &&
      other.top <= top + height);
}
methods.name: intersects

methods.desc: Returns a string representation of this object.
methods.name: toString

props.example:
Implementation

Point<T> get bottomLeft => Point<T>(this.left, this.top + this.height);
props.name: bottomLeft

props.example:
Implementation

Point<T> get bottomRight =>
    Point<T>(this.left + this.width, this.top + this.height);
props.name: bottomRight

props.desc:
The hash code for this object.

A hash code is a single integer which represents the state of the object that affects operator == comparisons.

All objects have hash codes. The default hash code represents only the identity of the object, the same way as the default operator == implementation only considers objects equal if they are identical (see identityHashCode).

If operator == is overridden to use the object state instead, the hash code must also be changed to represent that state.

Hash codes must be the same for objects that are equal to each other according to operator ==. The hash code of an object should only change if the object changes in a way that affects equality. There are no further requirements for the hash codes. They need not be consistent between executions of the same program and there are no distribution guarantees.

Objects that are not equal are allowed to have the same hash code, it is even technically allowed that all instances have the same hash code, but if clashes happen too often, it may reduce the efficiency of hash-based data structures like HashSet or HashMap.

If a subclass overrides hashCode, it should override the operator == operator as well to maintain consistency.
props.example:
Implementation

int get hashCode => _JenkinsSmiHash.hash4(
    left.hashCode, top.hashCode, right.hashCode, bottom.hashCode);
props.name: hashCode

props.example:
Implementation

Point<T> get topLeft => Point<T>(this.left, this.top);
props.name: topLeft

props.example:
Implementation

Point<T> get topRight => Point<T>(this.left + this.width, this.top);
props.name: topRight
